items.synopsis: Long-standing tensions between feuding family groups reached crisis point in the Northern Territory's remote west in early 2022. The response of two police officers has now been recognised.

image.altText: A man in a suit is interviewed for television.

items.synopsis: One of the taxpayers helped by ATO whistleblower Richard Boyle has spoken out for the first time, describing the prosecution of the person who gave him a lifeline as "insanity". Mr Boyle's wife has also spoken to 7.30 about the toll the six-year-long ordeal has taken on the couple.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces the prospect of four decades in jail. His wife says all he did was tell the truth

image.altText: One man wears a cap and blue check shirt and jeans smiling, another in denim jacket and shoulder length hair, smiling

items.synopsis: One of Australia's biggest rock bands, Silverchair ended with a whimper, not a bang. And so too did their friendships … almost.

title.children: 'We should have gone out in a blaze of glory': What really tore Silverchair apart

image.altText: Students in a classroom with male teacher in background.

items.synopsis: Poor mental health and excessive screen time are the biggest problems facing young people, according to a new survey of more than 2,000 Australian teachers. New resources will be made available for teachers in a hope to create more conversations on mental wellbeing.

title.children: 'Nervous rants' and crying at school: Teachers say poor mental health is the biggest issue facing Australia's youth

image.altText: For Rent sign

items.synopsis: The one-bedroom apartment was advertised as a delightful ground-floor apartment with its own private courtyard. Within a day the price was raised twice due to increased market interest.

image.altText: A long-haired man in a black wetsuit stands on the sand, holding a long yellow surfboard with a snake on the front of it.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Gold Coast man who took pet snake surfing slapped with fine. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A man who was filmed surfing with his pet python at a Gold Coast beach has been fined $2,322 for breaching his permit. Earlier this month, footage was shared online of Surfer Higor Fiuza and his three-year-old bredli carpet python, Shiva, gliding through Rainbow Bay. Senior Wildlife Officer Jonathan McDonald from the Department of Environment and Science says a fine has since been handed to Fiuza. "Our investigation found the man had a permit to keep native animals, but he was issued with a penalty infringement notice for the breaching section 88a of the Nature Conservation Act ," he says. " Permit holders are not allowed to take animals from their licenced premises unless taking them to a vet or, selling or giving the animal to another permit holder or taking it to an authorised display." He says taking native pets out in public could cause them "unecessary stress" or to behave in "an unpredictable way". "There is also the threat of spreading diseases to native wildlife when people take captive-bred reptiles out in public," he says. "Snakes are obviously cold-blooded animals, and while they can swim, reptiles generally avoid water. "The python would have found the water to be extremely cold, and the only snakes that should be in the ocean are sea snakes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gold Coast man fined for taking pet snake surfing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The first foal of champion racehorse Winx is tipped to break sale records as her owners confirm she will be sold at a public auction in Sydney next year. Winx is the only horse to win 33 consecutive races in the past 50 years, including 25 Group 1 wins, notching up more than $24 million in prize money. Her highly anticipated filly was born in the Hunter Valley in October last year, after a stillborn delivery in 2020. Bloodstock auctioneers Inglis will offer the Pierro x Winx filly at its prestigious Easter Yearling Sale in April 2024. Inglis Bloodstock Sales chief executive Sebastian Hutch wouldn't speculate on a price but anticipated she would attract "an extraordinary amount of attention" from around the globe. "It's very rare that a filly out of a mare like Winx would get offered for sale anywhere in the world," he said. "[She's a horse of] definitively unprecedented quality in the context of the Australian market and very, very rare in the context of the global bloodstock market. "It would be a mistake to think the popularity of this filly would be based exclusively on her parents, she's a very well conformed horse in her own right." You can read the rest of the story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: First foal of champion racehorse Winx to be offered for sale

featuredLink.title: 'The next chapter of a great story': Owners to sell Winx's first foal

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians have until 8pm (local time) tonight to enrol to vote or update their details ahead of the Voice referendum vote. Just like an election, all Australian citizens aged 18 and over must vote in a referendum. Since the announcement of the Voice referendum, the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) says there have been more than 270,000 enrolment transactions. The AEC says this referendum "will have the most complete roll of any national election or referendum in history". "If you’ve turned 18, become an Australian citizen or moved house since the 2022 federal election then don’t forget to take action," the AEC says. The vote will be held less than a month from now on October 14 .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Enrolment for Voice referendum closes 8pm tonight

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has followed Wall Street's lead and opened lower on Monday, down 0.6% to 7,235 points at 10:25am AEST. (For live figures at any time, jump to the post at the very top of the blog.) All sectors are in the red, with academic and educational services down the most, falling 1.5%. Energy has dipped 1.2%, while technology and consumer non-cyclicals are down 1.1% each. Basic materials has suffered the smallest drop, down by 0.1%. The top early performers so far: Silver Lake Resources +2.9% Ramelius Resources +2.5% Newcrest Mining +2.2% Star Entertainment Group +1.8% Bellevue Gold +1.7% The bottom five performers so far: Washington H Soul Pattinson: -5.1% Link Administration -3.9% Xero -3.6% Genesis Minerals -3.2% Credit Corp Group -3.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red as gold miners snatch early gains

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Buy now, pay later company Zip has tapped a former Westpac finance executive as its next chief financial officer. Gordon Bell will replace Martin Brooke, who steps down from the role on September 29. Mr Bell will formally begin as Zip's CFO on October 2. "We look forward to welcoming an executive of Gordon's calibre and experience to Zip's group executive team," Zip's managing director and group CEO Cynthia Scott said. "His track record of deep financial services and capital markets experience and demonstrated financial and people leadership shills will help us execute on our strategy and deliver valuable returns for all stakeholders."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Zip appoints ex-Westpac executive as its new chief financial officer

children.content: has tapped a former Westpac finance executive as its next chief financial officer.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has released new figures to try and shut down growing calls to introduce nuclear power into Australia's future energy mix from the Opposition. The government's current plan is to invest in clean energy projects through what's known as "Rewiring the Nation" at a cost of $20 billion. But the opposition has argued nuclear is cheaper and more reliable. Energy Minister Chris Bowen says new analysis shows introducing nuclear power to replace retiring coal-fired power stations would cost $387 billion. "The opposition is proposing small modular reactors, which are 300 mega watts each which means you need a lot of them to replace the retiring coal-fired power," he said. "In fact, you need 71 of these reactors to r eplace 21 gigawatts of coal fire power we have in the system. "It's a unicorn and a fantasy."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'A unicorn and a fantasy':  Energy minister blasts Coalition's calls to introduce nuclear power
